page.title: 15Chislehurst Caves
page.content:
Although known as Chislehurst Caves these are a series of old mines consisting of a 22 mile length of arched chalk passages.The passages are from 7ft to 12ft high and 6ft to 10ft wide and a section is open to the public.
The chalk was probably used as the foundations for buildings or roads,for lime smelting and may have been carried back to Newcastle as ballast in the sailing barges that had brought coal to the Thames ports.
The history of the mines is uncertain but it is claimed they were used by the Druids, the Romans and the Anglo-Saxson farmers for religious ceremonies and as hiding places.They were used as an ammunition store in the 1st World War and as an air raid shelter in the 2nd.
